questions.text: Skin has complex communities of bacteria, fungi, and viruses. All are the various skin commensals we should be aware of while detecting skin infections except:
questions.correct_answer: C. Malassezia species and mycobacteria species
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malassezia species and mycobacteria species Mycobacterial species are not commensal microbes on the skin. Malassezia and potentially pathogenic mycobacteria are not typical commensals we necessarily need to consider during initial detection of most skin infections.

Highyeild:

Skin microbiome: Approximately 1 million bacteria (involving hundreds of distinct species) inhabiting each square centimetre of skin. The composition of these organisms depends on sebaceous gland concentration, moisture content, and temperature , as well as on host genetics and exogenous environmental factors. Bacteria: Actinobacteria represents the largest phylum and includes Propionibacteria and Corynebacteria Firmicutes include Clostridia and Bacilli, the latter including the class Staphylococcus. Bacteroidetes and Proteobacteria Fungi: Malassezia are commonly found all over the body except for the feet.

Random:

Explanation of incorrect options: Option A . Actinobacteria - Propionibacteria and Corynebacterium: These are common bacteria found on the skin, especially in oily areas. Propionibacterium acnes plays a role in acne development. Option B . Firmicutes- Clostridia and Bacilli: Some species of these bacteria are normal inhabitants of the skin, although their role is less well-understood compared to others. Option D . Bacteroidetes and Proteobacteria: While these groups are more prevalent in the gut microbiome, some species can also be found on the skin in smaller numbers.

questions.text: Choose the incorrect option for the changes seen in specific disorders as below
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acanthosis- Pemphigus Acanthosis refers to thickening of the spinous layer (stratum spinosum) of the epidermis. This is a feature of psoriasis, not pemphigus. Pemphigus , on the other hand, is another blistering skin disease, but it's caused by autoantibodies that target desmoglein, a protein in desmosomes (cell-adhesion structures). This leads to acantholysis , but not acanthosis .

Highyeild:

Histology finding Condition in which seen Acanthosis Thickened spinous cell layer – Seen in psoriasis, lichen planus, chronic eczema Colloid body (Civatte body/Cytoid body) Degenerated dead keratinocytes seen as eosinophilic hyaline ovoid bodies in lower epidermis and dermis. Seen in lichen planus. Epidermotropism Migration of malignant lymphocytes from the dermis into the epidermis. Seen in mycosis fungoides (a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma) Hypergranulosis An increase in thickness of the granular layer of the epidermis. Seen in lichen planus Parakeratosis Nucleated stratum corneum. Seen in psoriasis Papillary tip microabscess Accumulation of neutrophils in the dermal papilla in dermatitis herpetiformis Spongiform pustule of Kogoj Accumulation of neutrophils in the stratum spinosum in psoriasis

Random:

Explanation of incorrect options: Option A . Spongiosis- Eczema: Spongiosis refers to intercellular edema in the epidermis, a hallmark feature of eczema. Option B . Acantholysis- Bullous impetigo: Acantholysis is the loss of adhesion between skin cells, causing blisters. Bullous impetigo is caused by a bacterial toxin that disrupts this adhesion. Option C . Munroe microabscesses- Psoriasis: Munro microabscesses are collections of neutrophils within the epidermis, a characteristic finding in psoriasis.

questions.text: The below instrument is frequently used in dermatology. The name of this instrument is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Punch biospy This is a standard instrument which is used in dermatology to diagnose various diseases by biopsy. This instrument is called punch biopsy instrument. It is a rotating metallic object. Procedure: The clinician holds the instrument perpendicular to the anesthetised skin. The punches pushed into the skin with a downward twisting movement A small cylinder of skin is taken out for histopathology.

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon of the lesion below. This phenomenon is seen in all diseases except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Eczema The phenomenon being shown is called Koebner’s response (isomorphic response). It refers to development of lesions in previously normal skin that has been subjected to trauma (like scratching, injury, friction, surgical incisions). The new lesions resemble the initial lesion (“iso” means same, “morphic” means morphology)

Highyeild:

True Koebner’s False Koebner’s Reverse Koebner’s Psoriasis Wart (verruca) Psoriasis Lichen planus Molluscum Vitiligo Reverse Koebner’s phenomenon: Lesions do not increase, instead reduce after trauma (each lesions needs to be traumatized to reduce them). Some psoriasis patients can have true koebner’s, while some have reverse koebner’s.

questions.text: The structure shown in the arrow is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Desmosome The structure connecting the keratinocytes is called desmosome. It is also called as an intercellular junction as it connects the cells together Hemidesmosome connect the basal cell to the dermo epidermal junction. This structure is damaged in autoimmune diseases like bullous pemphigoid. Envelope proteins are inside the cell and not in between.

Random:

Explanation of Other Options: Option A . Hemidesmosomes connect the basal layer of keratinocytes to the basement membrane, not to each other. Option C . Langerhans cells are immune cells residing within the epidermis, not structures connecting them. Option D . Envelope proteins are generally not specific to keratinocyte connections.

It involves only skin and eyes Pseudoxanthoma elasticum is a group of rare connective tissue disorders that affect the elastic connective tissue of skin, eyes and blood vessels.

CVS : Peripheral artery disease, carotid stenosis GI or Urinary bleeding Reduced pulmonary function

questions.text: Examination of transient neonatal pustular melanosis shows?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neutrophils Transient neonatal pustular melanosis It is an idiopathic pustular eruption of the newborn that heals with tiny brown pigmented macules. Lesions are usually present at birt h but may appear as late as 3 weeks of age. Features: superficial vesicles and pustules with collarettes of scale. Pigmented macules are also present at the sites of resolving pustules or vesicles. A smear of the vesicles shows a predominance of neutrophils. It is a self-limiting condition.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with asymptomatic yellowish nodules over the periorbital area as shown in the image. What is the investigation of choice?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Serum lipid profile The above clinical picture shows Xanthelasma which is plane xanthoma.

Highyeild:

Xanthelasma It is a skin lesion caused by the accumulation of fat in macrophages in the skin. Cause: Primary dyslipidemia - type III hyperlipoproteinemia Obesity Diabetes mellitus Chronic cholestasis Feature: Starts as a small bump that enlarges slowly over several months. Presents as soft, yellow, or yellow-orange macules, papules, or plaques. It often occurs with normal levels of circulating lipids. The investigation should include a full lipid profile and liver function tests.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Complete blood count: this is a routine blood test that measures various components of blood. It is not useful for the diagnosis of xanthelasma. Option C. Renal function tests: These measures creatinine and blood urea nitrogen, in the blood to assess kidney function. These tests are not relevant to the diagnosis of xanthelasma. Option D. Serum vitamin D levels: It measures the amount of vitamin D in the body. While vitamin D deficiency can cause various skin disorders, it is not relevant to the diagnosis of xanthelasma.

questions.text: A mother comes to OPD with her 1-week-old neonate with lesions over his hand and body. On examination, thin-walled superficial vesicles are noted. A disorder eccrine sweat gland is suspected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Miliaria The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Miliaria which is caused by obstruction of the free flow of eccrine sweat to the skin surrounding the face, sweat is retained resulting in signs and symptoms.

Highyeild:

Miliaria Common skin disease caused by a blockage or inflammation of eccrine sweat glands. It is aka heat rash, sweat rash, or prickly heat Occurs in 9% of neonates (mean age 1 week), and can also occur in adults Based on HPE it is divided into Association: Hot and humid climate, fever, hospitalized and bedridden patients Features: Miliaria crystallina : Clear, thin-walled vesicles which rupture to from superficial branny desquamation Miliaria rubra: Minute erythematous papules with a picking sensation Miliaria profunda : Pale, the firm applies with no itching. Treatment: Minimise heat and humidity, calamine lotion, emollients, mild topical steroids

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Bromhidrosis: Characterized by foul-smelling sweat usually due to infection of apocrine glands. Option C. Hidradenitis suppurativa: It is a disease of apocrine sweat glands defined by recurrent inflamed nodules in apocrine sweat glands. Option D. Fox-Fordyce disease: It is a disease of apocrine glands seen in females in 2nd decade, presenting with itchy patches in the axilla

questions.text: A 16 years old girl presents with multiple papulonodular, erythematous lesions on her face and was diagnosed with acne vulgaris. Which of the following is a pathognomic lesion of the same?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Comedones Comedones are specific for Acne vulgaris.

Highyeild:

Comedones (single-comedo) These are skin-colored, small bumps (papules) frequently found on the forehead and chin of those with acne. It is formed by the debris blocking the sebaceous duct and hair follicle They can be divided into: Open comedones- black-heads: When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment Closed comedones- white heads: When the keratin plug is inside the follicle Comedones are the earliest lesion of acne Stages of Acne Microcomedone Open or Closed comedone Papule or pustule Cyst or nodule

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A, B, & C: Nodules, Pustules, and Cysts: Although are seen in acne vulgaris but are not pathognomonic.

questions.text: A teenager presents to OPD with papulopustular lesions on the face and the presence of comedones. Which of the following is affected?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pilosebaceous unit The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Acne vulgaris which is caused by chronic infection of the pilosebaceous unit.

Highyeild:

Acne It is a chronic disorder affecting the hair follicle and sebaceous gland. Pathogenesis: Hypercornification of hair follicle opening The proliferation of P. acnes Excess sebum production Increase androgen secretion & IGF-1 Features: Open and closed non-inflamed comedones Inflamed papules and pustules Severe acne: Nodules and pseudocysts Post-inflammatory erythematous or pigmented macules and scars Severity: Mild acne : total lesion count <30 Moderate acne : total lesion count 30–125 Severe acne : total lesion count >125 Treatment: Mild acne: Topical anti-acne agents: benzoyl peroxide, azelaic acid, Antiseptics: Salicylic acid, Light/laser therapy Moderate acne: Tetracycline, Isotretinoin Severe acne: Oral antibiotics, oral isotretinoin

Random:

Explanation of incorrect options: Option A : Sweat unit: Sweat units are not typically associated with the development of acne. Acne vulgaris primarily involves the pilosebaceous unit, which consists of the hair follicle and sebaceous gland, leading to the formation of comedones and acne lesions. Option C : Hair follicle: While the hair follicle is part of the pilosebaceous unit involved in acne pathogenesis, the primary focus in acne vulgaris is on the sebaceous gland and its interaction with the hair follicle. The hair follicle alone is not the main structure affected in acne. Option D : Dennis: The term "Dennis" does not relate to the anatomical structures involved in acne vulgaris. It is not a recognized term in dermatology or acne pathophysiology.

questions.text: Fox-Fordyce disease involves which of the following sites?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Fox-Fordyce disease involves multiple sites on the body where apocrine glands are found. Based on the provided sources, the correct answer to the question is D) All of the above

Highyeild:

Fox-Fordyce disease It is aka apocrine miliaria Age: Post-pubertal women of age 13 and 35 years Cause: Apocrine sweat becomes trapped by a keratotic plug in the hair follicle. The apocrine sweat ducts within the epidermis rupture and leak to cause inflammation and intense itch. Sites: Apocrine gland-rich area Axilla Areola Anogenital area Umbilicus Perineum Medial aspects of the upper thigh Features: Dome-shaped flesh-colored to small reddish papules affecting almost every hair follicle in the area Bilateral Dark, thickened, dry skin as a consequence of scratching (lichenification) Reduced or absent sweating in the affected area.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 2-year-old history of erythematous papulopustular lesions on the convexities of the face. There is a background of erythema & telangiectasia. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rosacea The given clinical scenario of a 40 years old woman with erythema and papules on facial convexities is suggestive of Acne rosacea.

Highyeild:

Rosacea Chronic inflammatory skin conditions predominantly affecting the central face Age: 30 to 60 years, females (middle-aged women) Cause: Genetic susceptibility Altered microbe of skin and gut UV radiation Impaired skin barrier Pathogenesis: Altered innate immune response. Increased Toll-like receptor 2 Features: Transient flushing Persistent facial erythema Telangiectasia Inflammatory papules and pustules (papulopustular) Phymatous changes-Thickening of the skin Treatment: Sunscreen Topical metronidazole Oral doxycycline, low-dose isotretinoin

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Acne vulgaris: commonly occurs in adolescents and is characterized by comedones, papules, pustules, and nodules. Option C. SLE: Features include malar rash, which affects the convexities of the face, with characteristic nasolabial fold sparing. Systemic features like joint pain, swelling, edema, and features of kidney and blood involvement are also common. Option D. Polymorphic light eruption: It is a rash caused by exposure to the sun, appearing as tiny inflamed bumps or slightly raised patches of skin.

questions.text: A young female presented to dermatology OPD with nodulocystic acne and hair loss with the classical female pattern of AGA. Diagnosis of Hormonal Acne was made. What is the effect of oral contraceptives on these types of acne?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Beneficial effect on acne Giving oral contraceptives reduces free androgens by increasing the sex hormone binding- globulin.

Highyeild:

Hormonal acne Acne, a disease of the pilosebaceous unit is It is common in adolescence and may persist into adulthood, Pathogenesis: Sebaceous gland hypersensitivity to circulating androgens is believed to be the main factor. Testosterone and dihydrotestosterone (DHT) bind nuclear androgen receptors (AR), which then interact with deoxyribonucleic acid in the nucleus of sebaceous cells and ultimately regulate genes involved in cell proliferation and lipogenesis Androgen-insensitive persons do not develop acne as they do not produce sebum, and high androgen states are associated with acne. Features: Lesions along the jawline and chin, New-onset adult acne, Cystic acne with/without menstrual irregularities, and With Cyclical flares due to Fluctuations in the levels of androgens could (pre-menstrual aggravation.) Treatment : By reducing circulating androgens, Increasing sex hormone-binding globulin, Inhibiting 5α-reductase and Blockade of androgen receptors, Oral contraceptives

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Worsens acne by increasing seborrhea: It doesn’t worsen the acne. But used as a treatment modality for the same Option B. No effect on acne: It reduces free androgens. So it reduces the acne. Option D. Forms scar: It doesn’t form scar

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with multiple pus-discharging abscesses and sinuses and mutilating scarring on the gluteal region and back prevalent for the last ten years with exacerbations and remissions. Diagnosis of Acne conglobate was made. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isotretinoin The given clinical scenario is of acne conglobata and the drug of choice for the same is Isotretinoin. Isotretinoin: It targets multiple aspects of the disease, including reducing sebum production, inflammation, and bacterial colonization

Highyeild:

Acne conglobata It is a variant of nodulocystic acne The rare and severe form is seen predominantly in males Associated with: Hidradenitis suppurativa, dissecting cellulitis of the scalp Pyoderma gangrenosum- PAPA syndrome Features: Highly inflammatory nodules Form abscess, draining sinus traces, and comedowns Severe scarring Treatment: DOC: Isotretinoin Prednisolone

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Doxycycline: It is an antibiotic medication that is often used to treat acne vulgaris , but it is not typically effective in treating acne conglobata, which is a more severe and chronic form of acne that involves deep abscesses and scarring . Option B . Prednisolone: It is a corticosteroid medication that is primarily used to reduce inflammation and suppress the immune system. While it may provide some relief of symptoms in severe cases of acne conglobata , it is not considered a first-line treatment for this condition. Option D. Dapsone: It is an antibacterial and anti-inflammatory medication that is often used to treat dermatological conditions such as acne vulgaris, leprosy, and dermatitis herpetiformis. While it may provide some relief of symptoms in acne conglobata, it is not considered a first-line treatment for this condition.
